title: The First Human and the Beautiful Garden

scenes.text: Before any humans walked the Earth, Allah told the angels a special plan: â€œI will create a new caretaker for the Earth.â€ The angels knew Allah is Allâ€‘Wise and listened with respect.
Allah gathered gentle clay from different placesâ€”soft, sandy, red, brownâ€”and shaped it with perfect care. From this clay, Allah formed the body of the very first human: Adam.
Allah breathed life into Adam. His eyes opened to the bright sky, his ears heard the soft breeze, and his heart beat for the first time. Adam was alive by Allahâ€™s command!
Allah taught Adam the names of everythingâ€”the sun, the moon, rivers, birds, and trees. This knowledge was a gift that even the angels did not have. The angels admired Adamâ€™s new wisdom.
Allah told the angels to show respect to Adam. They all bowed except Iblis, who refused out of pride. Because of his arrogance, Iblis was sent away and became an enemy to humans.
Allah created Hawwa so Adam would have a loving companion. They lived together in the beautiful garden of Jannah with rivers, flowers, and fruits of every color. They felt safe and happy.
Allah said kindly, â€œEnjoy every blessing here, but do not eat from that one tree.â€ Adam and Hawwa agreed, grateful for all they had. Obeying Allah was their promise.
Iblis whispered lies, trying to trick them: â€œTaste the special tree and youâ€™ll live forever!â€ They forgot Allahâ€™s warning and ate from the forbidden tree. Their hearts felt heavy at once.
Realizing their mistake, they cried to Allah: â€œWe were wrong. Please forgive us!â€ Their tears were sincere. They learned that saying sorry to Allah is the first step back to goodness.
Allah, the Most Merciful, forgave them and sent them to Earth with guidance: follow My path and you can return to Jannah. Adam became the first prophet, teaching his children to obey and love Allah.

lesson: When we make mistakes, we should say sorry to Allah. Allah is the Most Merciful and always forgives those who truly repent!

title: The Great Ship of Peace

scenes.text: Long ago, in a land of golden dust and ancient trees, lived a man named Nuh. He was a very kind man with a heart full of love for the Creator. Nuh spent his days helping others and reminding them to be good, to be fair, and to thank Allah for the sun, the stars, and the rain.

But most of the people in his town had forgotten Allah. They were busy with their own lives and did not listen. Nuh would say gently, "Please, remember the One who gives us everything." But they only turned away.

Then, a special message came to Nuh. Allah told him that a great flood would soon wash over the land to make the world clean and new again. Nuh was told to build a massive ship, an Ark, made of sturdy wood and strong nails. Nuh picked up his tools, ready to follow the command with all his strength.

Day after day, Nuh worked on the Ark. He cut strong trees and shaped them with care. The sun beat down and the wind blew dust, but Nuh never stopped. He hammered and sawed, building the biggest ship anyone had ever seen.

The neighbors came to watch and point. "A ship in the desert?" one neighbor shouted, clutching his sides with laughter. "Where is the water, Nuh? Are you going to sail on the sand?" Nuh did not get angry. He simply wiped the sweat from his forehead and kept working, knowing that safety lay in being obedient.

When the Ark was finished, a wonderful thing happened. Animals of every kind began to arriveâ€”two by two. There were tall giraffes, tiny mice, colorful birds, and even crawling insects. Nuh welcomed them all aboard.

A young boy named Zayd helped the smaller creatures. He cradled two fluffy white sheep in his arms, making sure they felt safe. Overhead, birds of every color circled the Ark, waiting for their turn to fly inside. The air grew heavy and the sky turned a deep, dark grey. The first giant drop of rain fell with a plop on the dusty ground.

The rain came down harder and harder. The waters rose and lifted the great Ark. Thunder rumbled and lightning flashed, but inside the Ark, all were safe and warm. Nuh looked out at the endless water and whispered a prayer of thanks.

For many days and nights, the Ark sailed through the great blue world. Finally, the rain stopped, and the sun peaked through the clouds. Nuh sent a bird to look for land. When the bird returned with a green leaf in its beak, Nuh knew the earth was ready. The Ark came to rest gently on the peaks of Mount Judi.

The doors of the Ark swung open, and the animals rushed out into the fresh, clean air. Nuh and Zayd stepped onto the soft, wet earth. The world felt quiet and beautiful. Nuh raised his hands toward the sky in a prayer of thanks. A new story for the world was beginning, filled with hope and peace.

lesson: When we trust and obey Allah, He keeps us safe and gives us new beginnings.

title: The Great Search

scenes.text: Long ago, in a land of golden sands and tall palm trees, lived a young boy named Ibrahim. Ibrahim was very curious. While others in his town were busy making and bowing to statues made of cold stone, Ibrahim wondered about the world. He looked at the statues and thought, "These cannot speak, and they cannot move. Surely, the One who made everything is much greater than this."

One evening, Ibrahim sat with his father, Azar. The room was filled with many carved figures. "Father," Ibrahim asked gently, "why do we bow to things we made with our own hands? Should we not look for the One who made the trees, the wind, and the stars instead?" Azar looked surprised, for he had never thought to ask such questions.

When the sun went down and the world turned quiet, Ibrahim walked out into the desert. He wanted to find the Creator of the universe. He sat on a smooth rock and looked up. The sky was like a giant velvet blanket, waiting to reveal its secrets. "I will wait," Ibrahim whispered, "until I find the truth."

As darkness fell, a bright star appeared in the sky. It sparkled like a diamond. "Could this be my Lord?" Ibrahim wondered. The star twinkled as if smiling back at him. Ibrahim watched it closely, his heart beating with hope.

But as the hours passed, the star began to sink lower and lower. Finally, it slipped behind the distant hills and vanished. Ibrahim sighed. He felt a little bit sad. "I do not love things that pass away," he said softly. "The Creator must be constant and always there."

Ibrahim's friend, Sadiq, walked by and saw him staring at the sky. "The moon is beautiful, isn't it?" Sadiq asked. Ibrahim nodded, but he watched closely as the night turned to morning. Slowly, the moon began to fade into the pale blue of the dawn. Ibrahim realized the moon was leaving, too.
"The moon is leaving too," Ibrahim thought quietly to himself. "It cannot be the Creator either. The One who made all things must be greater than the moon." His search continued.

Then the sun rose, grand and warm. Its golden light spread across the sand like a glowing river. "Surely this is the greatest!" Ibrahim said, feeling the warmth on his face. But he watched carefully, remembering how the star and moon had disappeared.

All day long, Ibrahim watched the sun travel across the sky. He felt its warmth on his skin. But as the evening came, the sun also began to dip down. It turned the clouds red and then, just like the star and the moon, it went away. Ibrahim smiled, for now he finally understood.

Ibrahim stood up and turned his face toward the sky. He didn't need to see a star or a moon to know the truth. "I have found my way," he said clearly. "I believe in the One who created the sun, the moon, the stars, and the earth. He is the One who never leaves." Ibrahim bowed down in the quiet desert, his heart full of peace and great faith.

lesson: When we search with a sincere heart, Allah guides us to the truth.

title: The Baby in the Basket and the Parting Sea

scenes.text: In Egypt lived a cruel king named Pharaoh. He hurt Bani Israel and was so proud he claimed to be a god. He feared a baby boy would end his rule.
When baby Musa was born, Allah inspired his mother to place him in a basket on the Nile. She trusted Allah with tears in her eyes and courage in her heart.
The basket floated safely to Pharaohâ€™s palace. His kind wife Asiya found Musa and felt love at once. Allah protected the baby right inside the palace of the king.
Baby Musa cried for milk. His sister Maryam suggested a nurseâ€”Musaâ€™s own mother! Allah reunited mother and child, just as He promised.
Musa grew strong and kind. After an accident defending someone, he left Egypt and traveled to Madyan, where he helped two sisters at a well.
He married one sister and worked as a shepherd. One night in the desert, Musa saw a glowing fire on a mountain and went to it for light.
There he heard Allahâ€™s voice: â€œO Musa, I have chosen you.â€ Allah filled Musaâ€™s heart with faith and gave him courage to return to Pharaoh.
Allah gave Musa miracles: his staff became a snake, and his hand shone bright. These signs would show Pharaoh that Allah is the One True God.
Musa and his brother Harun spoke kindly to Pharaoh, but he refused. Plagues and signs came, yet Pharaohâ€™s heart stayed hard.
At the sea, Allah split the water into a dry path for Musa and Bani Israel. They crossed safely. When Pharaoh chased, the sea closed. Allah saved those who trusted Him.

lesson: When we trust Allah completely, He makes the impossible possible! Even the sea will make way for those who have faith.

title: The Beautiful Dreamer

scenes.text: Young Yusuf had a kind heart and a shining face. One night he dreamed eleven stars, the sun, and the moon bowed to him. Excited, he told his father Yaqub.
Prophet Yaqub knew it was a special dream from Allah. He said gently, â€œKeep this dream secret; your brothers may get jealous.â€ Yusuf felt loved and careful.
The brothers grew jealous and made a bad plan. They took Yusuf to the countryside and dropped him into a deep well. They lied to their father that a wolf took him.
In the dark well, Yusuf prayed to Allah. A caravan stopped for water and found him. They took him to Egypt and sold him in the market.
A kind official, the Aziz, bought Yusuf and treated him well. Yusuf grew honest and wise, but good people are tested. A false accusation sent him to prison.
In prison, Yusuf stayed patient and helped people. Two prisoners asked about their dreams. Yusuf explained them kindly, saying knowledge comes from Allah.
Years later, the King dreamed of seven fat cows eaten by seven thin ones, and green and dry stalks. No one understood. They called Yusuf to explain.
Yusuf said, â€œThere will be seven years of plenty, then seven years of hunger. Save food during the good years.â€ The King knew Yusuf was truthful and wise.
The King freed Yusuf and made him minister in charge of storing grain. When hunger came, people arrived from far awayâ€”including Yusufâ€™s brothersâ€”seeking food.
Yusuf forgave his brothers and revealed, â€œI am Yusuf.â€ They were shocked, but he said Allah turned the hardship into good. His dream came true, and his family reunited.

lesson: When hard times come, stay patient and trust Allah's plan. He can turn our difficulties into something beautiful!

title: The Prophet and the Great Whale

scenes.text: Yunus was sent to the city of Nineveh. The people forgot Allah and did many wrong things. He invited them kindly, but they laughed and turned away.
Feeling sad, Yunus left without Allahâ€™s permission. He boarded a ship to sail far away, thinking his job was over.
A storm hit the ship. Waves crashed, and sailors panicked. They felt someone on board had done wrong.
They drew lots; it fell on Yunus. He knew he had rushed away. â€œThrow me overboard,â€ he said. The sailors sadly agreed to save the ship.
A huge whale, commanded by Allah, swallowed Yunus whole. Down in the darkness, he was safe but alone.
Inside, Yunus realized his mistake. He turned to Allah in the deepest night of the sea.
He prayed: â€œLa ilaha illa Anta, Subhanaka, inni kuntu mina ath-thalimeen.â€ (No god but You. Glory to You. I was wrong.)
Allah heard him. He ordered the whale to rise and place Yunus gently on shore. Yunus was sore but alive and forgiven.
Allah grew a shady plant to comfort him. Yunus rested and promised to be patient and wait for Allahâ€™s guidance.
He returned to Nineveh. This time the people listened and changed. The city was savedâ€”just as Yunus was saved when he turned back to Allah.

lesson: When we make mistakes, we should turn to Allah and ask for forgiveness. Allah loves those who admit their wrongs and sincerely repent!

title: The King Who Talked to Animals

scenes.text: Sulaiman was the son of Dawud. Allah gave him wisdom, a kind heart, and a kingdom where he could even understand the speech of animals.
Marching with his army, he heard a tiny ant warn her friends to hurry home. Sulaiman smiled and stopped everyone so the ants stayed safe.
He raised his hands and thanked Allah: â€œHelp me be grateful and use my power for good.â€ Even the smallest creatures mattered to him.
His special bird, the hoopoe, returned with news: a faraway queen in Sheba worshiped the sun instead of Allah.
Sulaiman sent a gentle letter inviting her to worship Allah. He wanted guidance for her people, not treasure or gifts.
Before she arrived, Sulaiman asked, â€œWho can bring her throne?â€ By Allahâ€™s permission, it appeared in an instant, showing Allahâ€™s power.
When the queen entered Sulaimanâ€™s palace, she saw a clear glass floor that looked like water and lifted her dress. She realized this was real craftsmanship, not magic.
She saw her throne and knew Sulaimanâ€™s strength came from Allah. Her heart opened to the truth and she chose to submit to the One God.
Sulaiman loved fine horses and once got distracted. He quickly remembered prayer comes first and turned back to Allah with thanks.
He used every giftâ€”wind, jinn, birds, peopleâ€”to build and teach with fairness. His true greatness was gratitude and kindness.

lesson: Allah gives us all special gifts and abilities. We should use them to help others and always be grateful to Allah!

title: The Brave Shepherd Boy

scenes.text: Dawud was a young shepherd who sang to Allah in the hills. Birds paused and mountains echoed his gentle voice.
Though small, he was brave. He trusted Allah and protected his sheep from wild animals with courage and care.
A giant soldier named Jalut frightened everyone. Each day he challenged the army, but no one dared to fight him.
Dawud brought food to his brothers at the battlefield. He heard the challenge and said, â€œI will face him with Allahâ€™s help.â€
He chose a sling and five smooth stones instead of heavy armor. His trust was in Allah, not in big weapons.
Jalut laughed at the small boy, but Dawud stood firm: â€œYou come with weapons, I come with Allah.â€ He spun his sling.
The stone flew like a star and struck Jalutâ€™s forehead. The giant fell, and the enemy ran. Allah gave victory to the humble shepherd.
People loved Dawudâ€™s courage and kindness. Allah later made him a king and a prophet who ruled with fairness.
Allah gave him the Zabur and a voice so beautiful that birds gathered to listen. Even iron became soft in his hands to shape armor.
Dawud taught that real strength is faith and gratitude. His son Sulaiman would also become a wise and just king.

lesson: With trust in Allah, even the smallest person can overcome the biggest challenges. True strength comes from faith!

title: The Patient Prophet

scenes.text: Prophet Ayyub was blessed with a loving family, good health, and many animals. Most of all, he had a heart that thanked Allah every day.
He shared his blessings, helped the poor, and praised Allah often. Shaytan became jealous and wanted to shake Ayyubâ€™s faith.
Tests began. Ayyub lost his animals and farms. His home was gone, and his children passed away. He still said, â€œAllah gave and Allah can take. Alhamdulillah.â€
Then he became very sick. Painful sores covered his body. Friends left him, but his wife Rahma stayed and cared for him gently.
Months turned to years. Ayyubâ€™s heart stayed patient. He told himself, â€œThis is a test. I will never lose hope in Allahâ€™s mercy.â€
Shaytan whispered, â€œWhy keep thanking Allah?â€ But Ayyub refused to complain. His love for Allah was stronger than the whispers.
When he was very weak, Ayyub made a soft dua: â€œMy Lord, hardship has touched me. You are the Most Merciful.â€ He trusted Allah completely.
Allah answered. â€œStrike the ground with your foot.â€ A spring of cool water burst forth. Ayyub drank and washed; his illness vanished.
Allah restored his health and gave him even more family and blessings than before. His patience had been beautiful to Allah.
Ayyubâ€™s story shows that hardships are tests, not punishments. If we stay patient and hopeful, Allah brings relief in amazing ways.

lesson: When difficult times come, we should be patient like Ayyub and never lose hope in Allah's mercy. After every hardship comes ease!

title: The Prophet of Amazing Miracles

scenes.text: Maryam was a devoted servant of Allah. Angel Jibreel brought her amazing news: Allah would bless her with a special son without a father.
By Allahâ€™s command, baby Isa was born under a palm tree in a quiet place. It was a pure miracle from Allah.
When Maryam returned, people questioned her. She stayed silent and pointed to baby Isa.
Baby Isa spoke from the cradle: â€œI am a servant of Allah. He gave me a book and made me a prophet.â€ Everyone was amazed!
As Isa grew, Allah gave him miracles: he shaped a bird from clay and it flew by Allahâ€™s permission; he healed the blind and the sick.
He even revived the dead by Allahâ€™s permission. Isa always said these wonders were from Allah, not from himself.
Isa and his disciples traveled teaching kindness, forgiveness, and worship of the One God alone.
When the disciples asked for a table from heaven, Isa prayed. Allah sent a feast and warned them to stay grateful.
Some plotted to harm Isa, but Allah protected him and raised him up. Allah will send him back one day with justice.
Muslims honor Isa as a mighty prophet. His life teaches that every miracle is from Allah, and true peace is in worshiping Him alone.

lesson: All miracles come from Allah alone. We should be humble like Isa and always give credit to Allah for everything good in our lives!

title: The First Teacher

scenes.text: Allah sent Idris, a descendant of Adam, when people began to forget the truth. Idris had a gift that changed the world.
He was the first to write with a pen, recording knowledge about stars, numbers, and worship so people would remember.
Under shady trees he taught sewing, fair building, and honest measuring. People loved learning useful skills from him.
Most of all, he taught: â€œThere is only One God. Worship Him alone.â€ Some listened; others turned away.
Idris prayed so much that angels knew his name. His good deeds rose like sweet scent, pleasing Allah.
He stayed patient when people mocked him, sharing truth kindly and knowing guidance comes from Allah.
An angel befriended him, amazed by his worship. Idris said, â€œI only want Allah to be pleased with me.â€
Allah allowed Idris to journey above the clouds and past the stars, seeing wonders no human had seen.
Allah honored him: the Quran says He raised Idris to a high stationâ€”a special reward for a faithful servant.
Idris shows that learning is a gift and knowing Allah is the best knowledge. Patience and worship lift us high.

lesson: Learning is a gift from Allah! Use your knowledge to help others and always remember that the best knowledge is knowing and worshipping Allah.

title: The Prophet and the Mighty Giants

scenes.text: Long ago, there lived a people called 'Ad. They were not ordinary peopleâ€”they were giants! They were taller than trees and stronger than any humans before or after them. They built huge buildings and towers that touched the clouds. Everyone was afraid of them.

But the people of 'Ad had forgotten Allah. They became proud and cruel. "Who is stronger than us?" they would boast. "No one can defeat us!" They forgot that it was Allah who gave them their strength. They worshipped idols instead of the One True God.

Allah sent Prophet Hud to guide his people. Hud was from the tribe of 'Ad himself, and he was known for being honest and wise. "O my people!" Hud called out. "Worship Allah alone! You have no god but Him. Will you not be grateful for all He has given you?"

The giants laughed at Hud. "Why should we leave our gods?" they mocked. "You're just one man! You can't make us change." They thought their strength made them invincible. They had no idea that true power belongs only to Allah.

Hud didn't give up. Day after day, he reminded his people about Allah's blessings. "Look at your strong bodies, your beautiful gardens, your springs of waterâ€”all from Allah! Why do you worship statues that cannot help you?" But still, most of them refused to listen.

"If what you say is true," the arrogant leaders challenged Hud, "then bring Allah's punishment upon us!" They thought they were so powerful that nothing could harm them. Hud warned them that Allah's punishment could come in ways they never expected.

Then the rain stopped. The hot sun beat down day after day. The gardens dried up, and the rivers shrank. The people of 'Ad looked at the sky, hoping for clouds. When they finally saw a dark cloud coming, they cheered! "Rain at last!" they cried.

But it was not rain inside that cloud. It was a terrible wind! The wind began to blowâ€”stronger and stronger, fiercer and fiercer. It howled like a thousand wolves. It lasted for seven nights and eight days without stopping. Nothing could stand against it.

The mighty giants who thought no one could defeat them were swept away like dry leaves. Their tall towers crumbled to dust. Only Hud and those who believed in Allah were saved. They had taken shelter, protected by their faith in the One True God.

The land of 'Ad became empty and silent. The once-proud buildings became ruins in the desert. Prophet Hud's story teaches us that no matter how strong we are, we are nothing without Allah. True strength comes from faith and humility, not muscles and buildings.

lesson: No matter how strong or powerful we think we are, we should never be arrogant. All strength comes from Allah, and we should always be humble and grateful.

title: The Miracle of the She-Camel

scenes.text: After the people of 'Ad were destroyed, another mighty nation arose called Thamud. They lived in a rocky land and became famous for carving beautiful homes right into the mountains! Their houses were like caves in the cliffsâ€”cool in summer and warm in winter.

The people of Thamud were clever builders, but they made the same mistake as 'Adâ€”they forgot Allah. They worshipped idols carved from stone. Allah sent them a prophet named Saleh, one of their own people, to guide them back to the truth.

"O my people!" Saleh called out. "Worship Allah! He is the One who made you from the earth and let you build your homes here. Ask forgiveness from Him and turn to Him in repentance. My Lord is always near and ready to answer."

The proud leaders of Thamud didn't want to believe. "Prove that your God is real!" they demanded. "Make a miracle appear from that big rock over thereâ€”a living she-camel, unlike any we've ever seen!" They thought this was impossible and would make Saleh look foolish.

Saleh prayed to Allah. Then, right before everyone's eyes, the solid rock began to shake and crack! Out came a magnificent she-camelâ€”huge and beautiful, with a baby camel following her! The people gasped in amazement. This was truly a miracle from Allah!

"This she-camel is a sign from Allah," Saleh told his people. "Let her eat and drink freely from the land. On one day, she will drink from the well, and on the next day, you may use it. Do not harm her, or a terrible punishment will come upon you."

For a while, the people obeyed. The she-camel roamed freely, and she gave so much milk that everyone could drink from it! Some people began to believe in Allah. But the wicked leaders became jealous and angry. They hated sharing with a camel.

One terrible day, some cruel men made an evil plan. They waited for the she-camel and attacked her! They killed the innocent animal that was Allah's special sign. When Saleh heard what they had done, his heart filled with sorrow. "You have only three days," he warned.

The people laughed at Saleh's warning. "Nothing will happen to us!" they said. But on the first day, their faces turned yellow. On the second day, their faces turned red. On the third day, their faces turned black. Then a mighty blast from the sky destroyed them all.

Only Saleh and the believers were saved. They left the land of Thamud forever. Today, you can still see the ruins of their mountain homes in Saudi Arabiaâ€”a reminder of what happens when people reject Allah's signs and harm His creation.

lesson: When Allah sends us signs and blessings, we must be grateful and take care of them. Harming Allah's creation brings serious consequences.

title: The Prophet Who Stood Alone

scenes.text: Prophet Lut was the nephew of Prophet Ibrahim. When Ibrahim traveled to spread the message of Allah, Lut went with him. They were close companions in faith. Later, Allah sent Lut to guide the people of a city called Sodom, near the Dead Sea.

The people of Sodom lived in a beautiful valley with green gardens and fresh water. But despite all these blessings, they had become very wicked. They did terrible things that no people before them had ever done. They had completely forgotten Allah and His laws.

Lut tried his best to guide them. "O my people!" he pleaded. "Fear Allah and stop your evil ways! These actions are harmful and wrong. Turn back to Allah before it's too late!" But the people only laughed at him and continued their wicked behavior.

The people of Sodom became angry at Lut for criticizing them. "If you don't stop preaching," they threatened, "we will throw you out of our city!" Lut had no supporters except his own small family. But he refused to give up speaking the truth.

One day, three handsome strangers came to Lut's door. They were actually angels in disguise, sent by Allah! Lut welcomed them into his home, but he was worried. He knew the wicked people of the city might try to harm his guests.

Word spread about Lut's visitors, and a mob gathered outside his house. They demanded that Lut hand over his guests! Lut stood bravely at his door. "Please, leave my guests alone!" he begged. But the mob pushed closer and closer.

Just when things looked hopeless, the angels revealed who they really were! "O Lut, we are messengers from your Lord. These people cannot harm you." With a wave of their hands, the angels made the mob blind! They stumbled away into the darkness.

The angels told Lut to leave the city with his family that very night. "Do not look back," they warned. "A terrible punishment is coming at dawn." Lut gathered his believing family members and they hurried away under the cover of darkness.

As the sun rose, a rain of stones fell from the sky upon Sodom! The earth shook and turned upside down. The beautiful city was completely destroyed. Sadly, Lut's wife looked backâ€”she had secretly sided with the wicked peopleâ€”and she was lost too.

Today, where Sodom once stood, there is the Dead Seaâ€”so salty that nothing can live in it. Lut's story reminds us to always stand for what is right, even when we stand alone. And it teaches us that following the wrong crowd leads to destruction.

lesson: Always stand up for what is right, even if you stand alone. Choose your friends wisely, and never follow the crowd into wrongdoing.

title: The Patient Son and the Sacred House

scenes.text: Prophet Ibrahim and his wife Sarah had waited many, many years for a child, but none came. Then Allah blessed Ibrahim with another wife named Hajar, and she gave birth to a beautiful baby boy. They named him Ismail, which means "Allah hears." Ibrahim was overjoyed!

But Allah had a special plan. He commanded Ibrahim to take Hajar and baby Ismail to a faraway desert valleyâ€”a place with no water, no trees, and no people! With a heavy heart but complete trust in Allah, Ibrahim obeyed and left his family there.

Hajar called out to Ibrahim as he walked away, "Is Allah commanding you to leave us here?" When Ibrahim nodded, Hajar's heart filled with peace. "Then Allah will not abandon us," she said confidently. She trusted Allah completely.

Soon their water ran out. Baby Ismail cried with thirst. Hajar ran desperately between two hillsâ€”Safa and Marwaâ€”searching for water or help. She ran back and forth seven times, never giving up hope that Allah would help them.

Then a miracle happened! The angel Jibreel struck the ground near baby Ismail's feet, and fresh water gushed up from the earth! This spring is called Zamzam, and it still flows today in Makkah! Hajar quickly gathered the water and thanked Allah for saving them.

The spring attracted travelers and birds. Soon a tribe called Jurhum came and asked to settle near the water. Hajar agreed, and a small town began to grow. Ismail grew up there, strong and kind. He learned to speak Arabic from the Jurhum people.

Years later, Ibrahim came back to visit and told Ismail about an amazing dream. "I saw myself sacrificing you, my son," Ibrahim said with tears in his eyes. Ismail understood this was a command from Allah. "Do what you have been commanded, father. You will find me patient, Insha'Allah."

Ibrahim prepared to obey Allah's command, and Ismail lay down willingly. But just as Ibrahim was about to sacrifice his beloved son, Allah called out, "O Ibrahim! You have fulfilled the dream!" Allah sent a ram from heaven to sacrifice instead. It was only a testâ€”and they both passed!

Then Allah gave Ibrahim and Ismail the most honorable task: building the Kaaba, the first house of worship for all of humanity! Father and son worked side by side, placing stone upon stone. "Our Lord, accept this from us," they prayed together.

When the Kaaba was finished, Ibrahim made a beautiful prayer: "Our Lord, make this a peaceful city, and send among its people a Messenger from themselves." Thousands of years later, that prayer was answered when Prophet Muhammad was born from Ismail's descendants!

lesson: True faith means trusting Allah even when we don't understand His plan. When we obey Allah with patience, He replaces our sacrifice with something even better!

title: The Gift of Laughter

scenes.text: Prophet Ibrahim and his wife Sarah were very oldâ€”Ibrahim was nearly 100 years old and Sarah was 90! They had always wished for a child together, but it had never happened. Yet Ibrahim never stopped praying to Allah, trusting that Allah could do anything.

One day, some special guests came to visit Ibrahim. They looked like travelers, but they were actually angels sent by Allah! Ibrahim welcomed them warmly and prepared a delicious meal of roasted calf. But strangely, the guests didn't eat anything.

The angels had come with amazing news. "Don't be afraid," they said. "We bring you good news of a wise son!" Sarah, who was listening from behind a curtain, couldn't believe her ears. A son? At her age? She laughed in surprise!

"Are you surprised at Allah's decree?" the angels asked gently. "The mercy of Allah and His blessings are upon you, people of this house." Sarah's laugh turned from doubt to joy. Allah could truly do anything! Nothing was impossible for Him.

And just as Allah promised, Sarah gave birth to a beautiful baby boy! They named him Ishaq, which comes from a word meaning "laughter," because Sarah had laughed when she heard the news. Ishaq brought so much joy and laughter to his elderly parents!

Ishaq grew up watching his father Ibrahim, learning how to worship Allah and be kind to others. Ibrahim taught him everything about faith, prayer, and trusting Allah. Ishaq was a gentle and obedient son who loved to learn.

When Ishaq became a young man, Allah blessed him with prophethood too! He continued his father's mission of teaching people to worship Allah alone. Ishaq married a good woman named Rifqa, and they had twin sons named Esau and Yaqub.

Ishaq's son Yaqub would grow up to become a great prophet too! And from Yaqub's children came the twelve tribes of Bani Israel. Many prophetsâ€”including Yusuf, Musa, Dawud, Sulaiman, and Isaâ€”all came from Ishaq's family line.

Ishaq lived a long and blessed life. He was known for his kindness, wisdom, and patience. When he grew old and his eyesight became weak, he continued to worship Allah and guide his family with gentle words of wisdom.

Prophet Ishaq reminds us that Allah's promises always come true, even when they seem impossible. Sarah laughed because she couldn't believe she would have a baby at 90â€”but Allah made it happen! Never doubt what Allah can do.

lesson: Nothing is impossible for Allah! Even when something seems too hard to happen, trust in Allah because He can do anything.

title: The Father with Beautiful Patience

scenes.text: Prophet Yaqub was the son of Prophet Ishaq and the grandson of Prophet Ibrahim. He was also called "Israel," which means "servant of Allah." From his family would come a whole nation! Yaqub was blessed with twelve sons, but his favorite was young Yusuf.

Yaqub loved all his children, but there was something special about Yusuf. When Yusuf told his father about his dreamâ€”eleven stars, the sun, and moon bowing to himâ€”Yaqub knew Allah had big plans for this boy. "Don't tell your brothers," Yaqub warned wisely.

The other brothers noticed their father's special love for Yusuf, and jealousy grew in their hearts. One terrible day, they took Yusuf away and threw him in a well! They came back with a bloody shirt and lied: "A wolf ate Yusuf!" Yaqub's heart broke into pieces.

But Yaqub didn't scream or curse. Instead, he said something beautiful: "Fa sabrun jameel"â€”"So patience is most fitting." He cried, yesâ€”his eyes became white from so many tearsâ€”but he never complained against Allah. This is what we call "beautiful patience."

Years passed, but Yaqub never forgot Yusuf. His other sons would tell him, "You're still thinking about Yusuf? You'll make yourself sick!" But Yaqub only said, "I complain of my sadness only to Allah." He knew only Allah could understand his pain.

Even when things seemed hopeless, Yaqub kept hoping. "O my sons," he told them, "go and search for Yusuf and his brother. Never give up hope in Allah's mercy! Only those who don't believe give up hope." What amazing faith Yaqub had!

Then one day, a caravan returned from Egypt with incredible newsâ€”Yusuf was alive! Not only alive, but he had become a powerful leader! The sons brought back Yusuf's shirt. When Yaqub put it on his face, his eyesight returned! Allah had answered his prayers!

The whole family traveled to Egypt to reunite with Yusuf. When Yaqub finally saw his beloved son after so many years, they hugged and cried tears of joy! And when Yaqub entered the palace, his sons and their mother bowed before Yusufâ€”just like the dream!

Yaqub lived his final years in Egypt, surrounded by all his children. Before he died, he gathered his sons and asked, "What will you worship after me?" They answered, "We will worship your God, the God of your fathersâ€”One Godâ€”and to Him we submit."

Prophet Yaqub teaches us the meaning of "sabr"â€”patience. He was sad, he cried, he missed Yusuf terriblyâ€”but he never blamed Allah. He kept praying, kept hoping, and kept trusting. And in the end, Allah reunited him with everything he had lost!

lesson: When we lose something we love, we should have beautiful patience like Yaqub. Keep praying, keep hoping, and never give up on Allah's mercy!

title: The Prophet of Fair Trade

scenes.text: In the land of Madyan, near a forest, lived a people who were very good at business. They bought and sold goods from travelers passing through. But there was a big problemâ€”they were cheaters! They would use tricks to steal from people.

When they sold things, they would use heavy weights to make it look like they were giving more. But when they bought things, they used light weights to pay less! They thought they were so clever, but Allah saw everything they did.

Allah sent Prophet Shuaib to guide them. Shuaib was known as "the speaker of the prophets" because he spoke so beautifully. "O my people!" he said. "Worship Allah and be fair in your business. Don't cheat people with false measures!"

Shuaib explained why honesty matters. "Give people their full rights. Don't spread corruption in the land. What remains with Allah is better for you, if you are believers. But I am not a guardian over youâ€”I can only advise you."

The people of Madyan didn't want to hear it. "Does your prayer tell you that we should leave the way our fathers did business?" they mocked. "Should we stop doing what we want with our own money? You think you're so wise!"

Shuaib tried to reason with them gently. "O my people, I only want to help you. I don't want to do what I forbid you from doing. I only want reform as much as I can. My success comes only from Allah. In Him I trust and to Him I turn."

But the leaders threatened Shuaib. "We will kick you out of our town, you and everyone who believes in you! Unless you return to our way of life!" Shuaib stood firm. "Even if we hate your ways? Going back would be lying against Allah after He saved us!"

Shuaib kept warning them day after day, but they refused to change. Finally, a terrible punishment cameâ€”a day of intense heat, then a mighty earthquake that shook their homes to the ground! The cheaters were finished, as if they had never lived there.

Shuaib and the believers were saved. He turned away from the ruined city sadly. "I delivered my Lord's message and gave you good advice. How can I grieve for people who refused to believe?" He had done his bestâ€”the rest was up to Allah.

Prophet Shuaib teaches us that honesty in business is part of our faith. Whether we're trading toys, sharing snacks, or doing any kind of dealâ€”we must be fair! Allah sees everything, and He loves those who are honest and just.

lesson: Always be honest and fair in everything you do. Cheating might seem smart, but it makes Allah angry. Honesty is always the best way!

title: The Gentle Brother

scenes.text: Prophet Harun was the older brother of Prophet Musa. While Musa was strong and brave, Harun was known for being gentle and soft-spoken. He had a beautiful way with words that could calm any situation. The two brothers loved each other dearly.

When Allah gave Musa the mission to face Pharaoh, Musa felt worried. He had a slight difficulty speaking clearly. So Musa made a special prayer: "O my Lord, appoint for me a helper from my familyâ€”my brother Harun. Strengthen me through him!"

Allah answered Musa's prayer! "We will strengthen your arm through your brother," Allah promised. "We will give you both authority, so they cannot harm you. With Our signs, you and those who follow you will be victorious!" The brothers were a perfect team.

Together, Musa and Harun went to Pharaoh's palace. While Musa spoke firmly about Allah's power, Harun's gentle words helped explain the message with kindness. Harun could calm people down when Musa's strength made them scared.

When the great escape from Egypt happened, Harun stood right beside his brother. He helped lead Bani Israel through the parted sea, comforting the frightened people. "Don't be afraid," he would say softly. "Allah is with us."

After escaping Egypt, Musa went up Mount Sinai to receive the Torah from Allah. He left Harun in charge of the people. "Take care of them," Musa said. "Be their guide and don't follow the way of troublemakers." Harun promised to do his best.

But while Musa was away, a troublemaker named Samiri tricked some people into making a golden calf to worship! Harun tried to stop them. "O my people, this is only a test! Your Lord is Allah alone!" But the people wouldn't listen to his gentle words.

When Musa returned and saw the golden calf, he was furious! He grabbed Harun angrily. But Harun explained calmly, "O son of my mother, the people thought I was weak. They almost hurt me! Don't let our enemies laugh at us. I am not one of the wrongdoers."

Musa understood. Harun had tried his best, but the people had been too stubborn. Musa forgave his brother and prayed: "My Lord, forgive me and my brother, and admit us into Your mercy. You are the Most Merciful of those who show mercy."

Harun was not just Musa's brotherâ€”he was also a prophet of Allah. He served Allah faithfully and helped Musa throughout his mission. Harun reminds us that gentleness and kindness are powerful qualities, and that brothers should always support each other.

lesson: Being gentle and kind is a strength, not a weakness. Like Harun, we should support our family and speak softly, even in difficult times.

title: The Prophet of Promises

scenes.text: In the Holy Quran, Allah mentions a righteous man named Dhul-Kifl. His name means "the one with a portion" or "the one who fulfilled." Not much is known about his story, but Allah praised him as someone very specialâ€”patient, righteous, and among the best of people.

Some scholars say Dhul-Kifl might have been a king or a leader who made a promise to Allah. He promised to fast during the day, pray at night, and never become angry when judging between people. It was a big promiseâ€”could he keep it?

Every single day, Dhul-Kifl kept his promise. He would fast from sunrise to sunset, even when he was hungry. He would stand in prayer at night, even when he was tired. And when people came to him with problems, he always stayed calm and fair.

One day, someone came to test Dhul-Kifl's patience. The person was rude and argued unfairly, trying to make Dhul-Kifl angry. But Dhul-Kifl took a deep breath and responded with kindness. He wouldn't break his promise to Allah!

The test came again and againâ€”people would be difficult on purpose, but Dhul-Kifl always stayed patient. He remembered that losing his temper would mean breaking his promise to Allah, so he controlled his anger every single time.

Dhul-Kifl showed everyone what it means to keep a promise. A promise to Allah is the most important promise of all! He didn't just say he would be goodâ€”he actually did it, day after day, year after year, no matter how hard it got.

Allah was very pleased with Dhul-Kifl. In Surah Al-Anbiya, Allah mentions him alongside great prophets like Ismail and Idris, calling them all patient and righteous. What an honor to be mentioned with such great names!

In another surah, Surah Sad, Allah again mentions Dhul-Kifl as one of the best people. He was someone who kept his word, worshipped Allah faithfully, and treated people with justice and patience. Allah remembered him forever in the Quran.

We might not know all the details of Dhul-Kifl's story, but we know what made him special: he made promises and kept them. He was patient when it was hard. He was fair when it was easier to be unfair. These qualities made him beloved to Allah.

Prophet Dhul-Kifl teaches us a simple but powerful lesson: keep your promises! When you say you'll do something, do it. When you promise to be good, be good. Allah loves people who are true to their word.

lesson: Always keep your promises, especially promises to Allah. Being patient and true to your word makes you beloved to Allah!

title: The Prophet Who Called to the One God

scenes.text: After the time of Prophet Sulaiman, the land of Israel was divided into two kingdoms. In the northern kingdom, people began to forget Allah. They started worshipping a false god called "Baal." Allah sent Prophet Ilyas to bring them back to the truth.

Ilyas was a brave and fearless prophet. He wasn't afraid to speak the truth, even to powerful kings! He went to the king and said boldly, "Why are your people worshipping Baal? He is nothing! There is no god but Allah, the Creator of everything!"

The queen was a wicked woman who loved the worship of Baal. She had built temples for this false god and made the people bow to statues. When she heard what Ilyas was saying, she became very angry and wanted to harm him.

But Ilyas wasn't scared. He challenged the priests of Baal to a test. "Let's see whose god is real!" he said. "We'll both prepare a sacrifice. You pray to Baal, and I'll pray to Allah. Whoever's god sends fire from the sky is the true God!"

The priests of Baal went first. They danced and shouted and prayed to their idol all day long. "O Baal, answer us!" they cried. But nothing happened. Their statue couldn't do anythingâ€”because it was just stone. It wasn't real.

Then Ilyas stepped forward. He raised his hands to the sky and called upon Allah. Immediately, fire came down from heaven and consumed the sacrifice! The people fell on their faces in amazement. "Allah is the true God!" they cried. "There is no god but Allah!"

For a moment, the people believed. But the wicked queen was still powerful, and many went back to their old ways after Ilyas left. Ilyas felt sad that people wouldn't stay on the right path. He continued preaching, but it was hard work.

Allah tells us in the Quran that Ilyas was among the messengers, and he said to his people: "Will you not fear Allah? Do you call upon Baal and leave the Best of creatorsâ€”Allah, your Lord and the Lord of your fathers?"

Allah honored Ilyas greatly. The Quran says: "Peace be upon Ilyas! Indeed, we thus reward the doers of good. Indeed, he was of Our believing servants." What a beautiful reward for staying true to Allah!

Prophet Ilyas teaches us to be brave in standing up for the truth. Even when others around us do wrong things, we should keep worshipping Allah alone. One person with the truth is stronger than a thousand people with falsehood!

lesson: Be brave in standing up for the truth! Even when others follow the wrong path, stay strong in your faith in Allah.

title: The Faithful Successor

scenes.text: Prophet Al-Yasa (also known as Elisha) was a very special man who learned from Prophet Ilyas. He followed Ilyas everywhere, learning about Allah and how to be a good prophet. When it was time for Ilyas to leave this world, Al-Yasa became the new prophet for his people.

Allah mentions Al-Yasa in the Holy Quran twice, alongside the greatest prophets. In Surah Al-An'am, Allah says: "And Ismail and Al-Yasa and Yunus and Lutâ€”all of them We favored above the worlds." What an honor!

And in Surah Sad, Allah mentions him again: "And remember Ismail, Al-Yasa, and Dhul-Kiflâ€”all are among the outstanding." Being called "outstanding" by Allah is the greatest praise anyone could receive!

Al-Yasa continued the work that Ilyas had started. He traveled through the land, teaching people to worship Allah alone and to leave the false gods behind. He was patient and kind, just like his teacher had been.

According to some stories, Allah gave Al-Yasa the ability to perform miracles. He could heal the sick and help people in amazing waysâ€”all by Allah's permission. People came from far away to seek his help and hear his teachings.

One famous story tells of a woman who was very poor and owed money to people. She came to Al-Yasa crying for help. Al-Yasa told her to gather as many empty jars as she could. Then, by Allah's miracle, her small amount of oil filled all the jars! She sold the oil and paid her debts.

Al-Yasa was known for his kindness to everyoneâ€”rich or poor, young or old. He never turned anyone away who needed help. He showed people that being close to Allah means being kind to Allah's creation.

Even though the Quran doesn't tell us many details about Al-Yasa's life, the fact that Allah mentioned him by name is very special. Allah doesn't mention anyone in the Quran unless they are truly important and righteous.

Al-Yasa spent his whole life serving Allah and helping people. When he grew old, he made sure to teach others what he knew, so the message would continue even after he was gone. He was a faithful servant until his last breath.

Prophet Al-Yasa teaches us the importance of learning from good teachers and continuing good work. When we learn something good, we should practice it and pass it on to others. That way, goodness never stops!

lesson: Learn from good teachers and continue doing good work! When we pass on what we learn, the goodness keeps going forever.

title: The Prophet Who Never Stopped Praying

scenes.text: Prophet Zakariya was a very old man who served in the temple in Jerusalem. His hair had turned white and his bones had become weak, but his heart was still young with love for Allah. There was just one thing that made him sadâ€”he had no children.

Zakariya and his wife had prayed for a child for many, many years, but none came. Now they were too oldâ€”it seemed impossible. But Zakariya had learned something important: nothing is impossible for Allah. So he kept praying.

Allah gave Zakariya a special jobâ€”to take care of a young girl named Maryam. She was a very pious girl who spent all her time worshipping Allah in the temple. Zakariya would check on her every day to make sure she had food.

One day, Zakariya entered Maryam's room and found fresh fruits that were out of season! "O Maryam, where did this come from?" he asked in amazement. Maryam replied, "It is from Allah. Indeed, Allah provides for whoever He wills without measure."

Hearing this, something sparked in Zakariya's heart. If Allah could send fruits out of season to Maryam, couldn't Allah also give him a child in his old age? Right there, right then, Zakariya raised his hands and made his beautiful prayer.

"My Lord," Zakariya prayed in secret, "my bones have become weak and my head is full of white hair. But I have never been disappointed in praying to You, my Lord! Grant me from Yourself an heir who will inherit from me and the family of Yaqub."

Allah heard Zakariya's quiet prayer. Angels came with wonderful news: "O Zakariya! We give you good news of a boy whose name will be Yahyaâ€”a name no one has had before!" Zakariya couldn't believe his ears! A son! After all these years!

"My Lord!" Zakariya exclaimed. "How can I have a son when my wife is barren and I am extremely old?" The angel replied, "It will be so! Your Lord says, 'It is easy for Me, and I created you before when you were nothing.'"

Zakariya asked for a sign that this miracle was really happening. Allah told him: "Your sign is that you will not speak to people for three nights, though you are healthy." Zakariya came out of the temple unable to speak, but his heart was singing with joy!

And just as Allah promised, a baby boy was born to Zakariya and his wife! They named him Yahya, and he grew up to become a great prophet too. Zakariya's story teaches us to never stop praying, no matter how old we are or how impossible things seem.

lesson: Never stop praying to Allah, no matter how impossible your wish seems. Allah can make anything happen! He loves those who keep asking Him.

title: The Pure-Hearted Prophet

scenes.text: Prophet Yahya was the miracle baby given to old Zakariya and his wife. His name was specialâ€”Allah Himself chose the name "Yahya," which no one had ever been called before! From the very beginning, Yahya was marked for greatness.

Even as a young child, Yahya was different from other kids. While they played and ran around, Yahya preferred to sit quietly and think about Allah. He loved animals and nature, and he was always kind and gentle to every living thing.

Allah blessed Yahya with wisdom even as a little boy. The Quran says: "O Yahya, hold firmly to the Scripture!" And Allah gave him wisdom while he was still a child. Imagine being so wise and close to Allah at such a young age!

Yahya was known for his pure heart. He never said bad words, never hurt anyone's feelings, and never disobeyed his parents. The Quran describes him as "dutiful to his parents, and he was not arrogant or disobedient."

As Yahya grew up, he chose to live a simple life. He didn't care about fancy clothes or delicious food. He would eat simple things like locusts and wild honey, and he wore rough clothes. His focus was only on worshipping Allah.

Yahya spent his time calling people to repent and turn back to Allah. "Clean your hearts!" he would tell them. "Stop doing wrong things and ask Allah for forgiveness!" Many people listened to his gentle but powerful words.

Allah gave Yahya several special qualities mentioned in the Quran: tenderness from Allah (a soft, caring heart), purity (he never sinned), and consciousness of Allah (always thinking about pleasing Allah). What a beautiful combination!

Yahya was also given an important jobâ€”to prepare the way for another great prophet who would come soon: Prophet Isa! Yahya taught people to be ready, to clean their hearts, and to believe in the Messenger who was coming.

Sadly, Yahya's life was cut short. Some wicked people didn't like his truthful teachings, and they harmed him. But Yahya died as a shaheedâ€”someone who is honored by Allah for standing up for the truth no matter what.

The Quran ends Yahya's story with beautiful words: "Peace be upon him the day he was born, the day he dies, and the day he will be raised alive." Allah's peace is with Yahya foreverâ€”what a wonderful reward!

lesson: Keep your heart pure and clean like Yahya. Be kind, be gentle, and always speak the truth. A pure heart is the most beautiful thing to Allah!

scenes.text: In the city of Makkah, in the Year of the Elephant, a special baby was born. His name was Muhammad, which means "the praised one." He was born into the noble tribe of Quraysh, but his father had already passed away. Allah had great plans for this child. ï·º

Young Muhammad ï·º was raised first by his grandfather Abdul Muttalib, and then by his uncle Abu Talib. He grew up to be the most honest and trustworthy person in all of Makkah. People called him "Al-Amin" (The Trustworthy) and "As-Sadiq" (The Truthful).

Even before becoming a prophet, Muhammad ï·º was different. He never worshipped the stone idols that filled the Kaaba. He was always kind to the poor, gentle with children, and respectful to elders. Everyone who met him loved him.

Muhammad ï·º would often go to a cave called Hira on a mountain near Makkah to think and pray. One night, when he was 40 years old, something amazing happenedâ€”the Angel Jibreel appeared! "Read!" the angel commanded. This was the first revelation of the Quran!

Muhammad ï·º received the message of Islamâ€”that there is only One God, Allah, and that all people should worship Him alone. He started teaching this message, first to his family and close friends, then to all of Makkah. Some believed, but many were angry.

The people of Makkah were mean to the Prophet ï·º and the early Muslims. They threw garbage at him, called him names, and even hurt his followers. But Muhammad ï·º never stopped being kind. He prayed for them and kept spreading the message with patience.

When things got very difficult, Allah took Muhammad ï·º on an incredible night journey called Al-Isra wal Mi'raj! He traveled from Makkah to Jerusalem, then up through the seven heavens, where he met previous prophets and received the gift of the five daily prayers!

Eventually, Muhammad ï·º and the Muslims moved to a city called Madinah, where people welcomed them with open arms. There, the Prophet ï·º built a community based on justice, kindness, and brotherhood. Muslims and even non-Muslims lived together in peace.

Years later, Muhammad ï·º returned to Makkah in a peaceful victory. He forgave everyone who had hurt himâ€”even his worst enemies! He cleaned the Kaaba of all the idols, and Makkah became a city of Islam. His kindness amazed everyone.

Prophet Muhammad ï·º is the final messenger of Allah, sent as a mercy to all of creation. He taught us how to pray, how to be kind, how to forgive, and how to love Allah. When we say his name, we send blessings: Sallallahu Alayhi Wa Sallam! ï·º

lesson: Prophet Muhammad ï·º showed us how to be the best person we can beâ€”kind, honest, patient, and forgiving. Let's follow his example every day!
